        Dax Eckenberg • 5 days ago

        This is a very useful if you have hosts in a traditional data center. This is counter to the "name nothing" paradigm for cloud computing. Instances ( with a random name ) will start, register themselves and the services they provide, and eventually un-register themselves ( or be tombstoned )

        The concept of hostnames implies that you'll actually do something with a particular host. If you're really embracing the cloud then you should never need access to a particular host. Centralized logging, metrics, etc should all be a foundational part of your cloud deployment. If you find yourself needing hostnames, you're not fully embracing the elasticity of the cloud.

        Now obviously you do need service names ( e.g. mail, www, ftp, logger, etc ) but well known hostnames should be avoided.

                Nick Wilkens Gyula Wéber • 5 days ago

                It depends -- and is based on how your infrastructure is organized, the tools used, and your preferences ;)

                For us -- it makes sense to monitor certain things via the A record -- to tie together hardware such as disk failure, raid failure, system temperatures etc. This gives us a picture of a particular machine --- an not necessarily the application that happens to be running on this machine.

                Other things like the database, web application, email, etc are monitored via the CNAME records.
